Attention Mechanisms

Bahnadau Attention mechanism

Let's start with training inputs x1,x2,...,xnx_1,x_2,...,x_nx1​,x2​,...,xn​ as input sequence and y1,y2,...,yny_1,y_2,...,y_ny1​,y2​,...,yn​ as target sequence.

Then we will have the following model:

  1. Compute hi=concat(hi,forward,hi,backward)h_i = concat(h_{i,forward},h_{i,backward})hi​=concat(hi,forward​,hi,backward​), encoding of 2 LSTM's, one ran forward and one ran backward only on xxx- the input sequence.
  2. Initialize s0s_0s0​ randomly
  3. Define a0,j=softmax(s0,hja_{0,j} = softmax(s_0,h_ja0,j​=softmax(s0​,hj​ for j=1..Nj=1..Nj=1..N.
  4. Define now c1=\Sumj=1..Nhj∗a0,jc_1 = \Sum_{j=1..N}h_j*a_{0,j}c1​=\Sumj=1..N​hj​∗a0,j​
  5. Postulate s1=f(s0,y0,c1)s_1 = f(s_0,y_0,c_1)s1​=f(s0​,y0​,c1​)
  6. Postulate y1=g(y0,s1,c1)y_1 = g(y_0,s_1,c_1)y1​=g(y0​,s1​,c1​)

Unroll the above in a loop, so it becomes:

  1. Define at,j=softmax(st−1,hja_{t,j} = softmax(s_{t-1},h_jat,j​=softmax(st−1​,hj​ for j=1..Nj=1..Nj=1..N.
  2. Define now ct=∑j=1..Nhj∗at,jc_t = \sum_{j=1..N}h_j*a_{t,j}ct​=∑j=1..N​hj​∗at,j​
  3. Postulate st=f(st−1,yt−1,ct)s_t = f(s_{t-1},y_{t-1},c_t)st​=f(st−1​,yt−1​,ct​)
  4. Postulate yt=g(yt−1,st,ct)y_t = g(y_{t-1},s_t,c_t)yt​=g(yt−1​,st​,ct​)

Note now after training we only use yyy in the last 2 equations, and yty_tyt​ appears only on the left-hand side of the last equation. This gives a way to generate yyy.

Output h(t)h^{(t)}h(t) is a function of input e(t)e^{(t)}e(t) and the output of the previous time step h(t−1)h^{(t-1)}h(t−1). h(t)=RNN(h(t−1),e(t))h(t) = RNN(h(t-1), e(t))h(t)=RNN(h(t−1),e(t))

hth^tht - is hidden state

If part of a whole, we can say hth^tht is a contextualized embedding of ete^tet.

Attention Networks

General Form : O=Att(Q,V)O=Att(Q,V)O=Att(Q,V) where all of the above are whole matrices:

Given a set of vector values VVV, and a set of vector queries QQQ, attention is a technique to compute a weighted sum of the values, dependent on each query.

The weights in the weighted sums are called attentions and denoted by α\alphaα.

So, then:

αi,j\alpha_{i,j}αi,j​ - weight for "query" iii on "value" jjj. alphaialpha_ialphai​ - attention for "query" iii.

where fff is some neural network.

The output oi=∑j=1..∣V∣alphai,j∗vjo_i= \sum_{j=1..|V|}alpha_{i,j}*v_joi​=∑j=1..∣V∣​alphai,j​∗vj​

Attention Variants

Unnormalized dot product attention.

Let aˉi,j=qi∗vj\bar{a}_{i,j} = q_i*v_jaˉi,j​=qi​∗vj​

ai,j=exp(ai,j)∑j(exp(ai,j))a_{i,j} = \frac{exp(a_{i,j})}{\sum_j(exp(a_{i,j}))}ai,j​=∑j​(exp(ai,j​))exp(ai,j​)​

vjout=∑j=1..ai,j∗vjv^{out}_j = \sum_{j=1..}a_{i,j}*v_jvjout​=∑j=1..​ai,j​∗vj​ is then the contextual representation The scaled version would be:

aˉi,j=qi∗vj(d)\bar{a}_{i,j} = \frac{q_i*v_j}{\sqrt(d)}aˉi,j​=(​d)qi​∗vj​​

Another version w/ some paramters would be:

aˉi,j=qi∗W∗vj\bar{a}_{i,j} = q_i*\bold{W}*v_jaˉi,j​=qi​∗W∗vj​ where W is a parameter matrix.

Problem w/ single- head attention is that softmax is quite 'sharp' and maybe there are multiple 'concepts' to learn (e.g. one is subject-object relation, another subject-verb, etc).

In multi-head attention, we can pre-project the embedding into a smaller space, and then concat the outputs.
